ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I developed my Chinese conversational skills and cultural understanding
I strengthened my Mandarin communication ability
I learned vocabulary related to social, political, and economic problems facing China today and in the past. I also practiced public speaking and essay-writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
Strengths: class periods are super helpful with adjusting students to conversation and making them more comfortable with the language

Weaknesses: some elements of the homework feel not as helpful to learning such as the handwriting quizzes, I think it would be more helpful to have more lingco vocab practice instead of the handwriting quizzes

Strengths: The course was very well structured. I felt like I was really learning something every class and the teacher had great energy. The course should have more presentations and less handwriting.

I loved that this class was only 3 times a week. I felt like it was the perfect amount of class time necessary to improve my Chinese but not over-burden my schedule. However, I think this class could've improved with less assignments. Some were helpful, but often it felt like busy work when I had to complete the Lingco vocab review sessions in particular.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, helpful for Chinese learning and lots of fun

Yes! You are looking at roughly 6 hours a week for this class: 3 hours of class time with 1 hour of homework before each of those classes. This sort of low-ish workload is a great way to freshen up your Chinese and be the next step in your journey.
Certainly. I'm surprised by how much I can understand now compared to when I started the class. The workload is heavy, but the homework always felt tangibly helpful. It never felt unreasonable.
I would, but only if you're interested in moving into more difficult topics, and not just conversational Chinese. It's a lot of work but it's very do-able, so long as you stay on top of your Canvas.
